monogr.title: The gunner : shevving the vvhole practise of artillerie: vvith all the appurtenances therevnto belonging. Together with the making of extra-ordinary artificiall fireworkes, as well for pleasure and triumphes, as for warre and seruice. VVritten by Robert Norton, one of his Maiesties gunners and enginiers
monogr.author: Norton, Robert
monogr.extent: 16, 100, 99-158, 4 pages, 27, 2 leaves of plates (25 folded), illustrations (woodcuts), 2Â°

div.head: The Authors Len-voy.
div.l: SInce now my Booke thou art so farre gone on,
Abroad on Gods name, and be better knowne:
But had there beene now but one quarter done,
That, nor the rest, should ne're haue seene the Sunne:
To friends be free, ope them, thy Treasures store,
But carping Scoffers let them haue no more
But Scraps, for that's enough and good for such
As poyson all they see, foule all they touch:
And on Mechanick scapes forge Arts detraction,
Ere they will winke or mend, which is the faultier Action?
The Errats made, theyle not, did I intend it
For such as not commend, nor can come mend it,
Not I, and so I end it.
